Reaction-driven protonation of pyridine nitrogen as active sites for efficient acetylene hydrochlorination Saisai Wang Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Formal analysis Data curation a † Zhixin Liu Validation Investigation Formal analysis Conceptualization a † Da Xu Visualization Validation a Siyu Pei Visualization Validation Conceptualization a Jianbo Wu Data curation a Kaixuan Zhuge Software a Chunxiao Jin Software a Haiting Cai Writing – review & editing Conceptualization a Renqin Chang Visualization Validation c Yuxue Yue Writing – review & editing Formal analysis a b Jia Zhao Writing – review & editing Investigation Funding acquisition a ⁎ Xiaonian Li Writing – review & editing Funding acquisition a a Industrial Catalysis Institute of Zhejiang University of Technology, Hangzhou 310014, China Industrial Catalysis Institute of Zhejiang University of Technology Hangzhou 310014 China aIndustrial Catalysis Institute of Zhejiang University of Technology, Hangzhou 310014, China b Department of Environmental Engineering, Zhejiang University of Technology, Hangzhou 310014, China Department of Environmental Engineering Zhejiang University of Technology Hangzhou 310014 China bDepartment of Environmental Engineering, Zhejiang University of Technology, Hangzhou 310014, China c Research Center of Analysis Measurement of Zhejiang University of Technology, Hangzhou 310014, China Research Center of Analysis Measurement of Zhejiang University of Technology Hangzhou 310014 China cResearch Center of Analysis Measurement of Zhejiang University of Technology, Hangzhou 310014, China ⁎ Corresponding author. † These authors contributed equally. Non-metallic catalysts present significant potential for environmentally friendly industrialization of acetylene hydrochlorination. However, the challenge of low activity in non-metallic catalysts hampers their practical application. In this study, we propose the use of a dual-template method to fabricate a layered N-doped carbon catalyst, subsequently applying it to acetylene hydrochlorination reactions. Experimental results indicate that the catalyst exhibits exceptional catalytic performance in acetylene hydrochlorination. Combined with characterization results, the catalyst's performance is positively correlated with its surface area and nitrogen content. Furthermore, DFT calculations suggest that protonated pyridinic nitrogen and pyridinic N + O − have moderate adsorption on HCl, potentially serving as active sites for the catalyst. This study analyzes the impact of various parameters of N-doped carbon catalysts on catalytic performance, providing direction for developing non-metallic catalysts suitable for industrial applications. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Acetylene hydrochlorination Metal-free catalyst N-doping Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Polyvinyl chloride (PVC), ranked as the world's third-largest polymer, acquires the vinyl chloride monomer needed for polymerization through the catalytic reaction of acetylene and hydrogen chloride. However, the use of HgCl2 catalyst in this production process poses substantial environmental challenges and poses severe risks to human health. A notable instance is the Minamata disease, recognized as one of the world's eight major environmental pollution incidents. In safeguarding public health, the international community unanimously embraced the Minamata Convention, imposing stringent restrictions on the utilization of toxic mercury (Hg) catalysts [1–6]. Considering the irreplaceability of the calcium carbide method, particularly in coal-rich China, the imperative development of more environmentally friendly, mercury-free catalysts has emerged as an exceptionally important research topic. Over the past few decades, researchers have predominantly concentrated on noble metal catalysts renowned for their high activity, such as Au [7–12], Pd [13–16], Pt [17–21], Ru [22–26]. However, the cost associated with noble metals and challenges linked to the reduction of catalytic active centers impose limitations on their applications. Non-noble metals, exemplified by Cu [27–31], generally exhibit lower performance and poorer stability compared to their noble metal counterparts. In contrast to metal catalysts, environmentally friendly carbon materials, distinguished by high defects, tunable surface properties, and robust mechanical strength, have garnered widespread attention in the realm of acetylene hydrochlorination. To investigate the active centers of carbon carriers, Li et al. [32]. selected nanodiamond and graphite-based carbons as catalysts. They adjusted the hybrid ratio (sp2: sp3) in the carbon carriers to scrutinize the influence of this ratio on the activity of carbon-based catalysts in acetylene hydrochlorination. The results reveal a volcano relationship between the surface hybrid structure of non-metallic carbon catalysts and their catalytic performance during the acetylene hydrochlorination process, specifically with nanodiamond-oriented and graphite-oriented carbon catalysts. The optimized surface sp2 content for nanodiamond-oriented carbon and the optimized surface sp3 content for graphite-oriented carbon both fall within the range of 32–35 %. It is noteworthy that, owing to the uniform charge distribution and structural stability of carbon-based materials, their interaction with reactants is weakened, leading to a failure of their catalytic performance to meet industrial requirements. Doping heteroatoms, such as N [33–39], B [40,41], P [42], S [43], etc., not only generates additional defect sites on the carbon base but also strengthens the adsorption and activation of reactants, thereby enhancing the catalytic performance of doped catalysts. Nitrogen doping, among these heteroatoms, has attracted significant attention due to the ease of obtaining nitrogen sources and the exceptional catalytic performance demonstrated by nitrogen-doped catalysts. In a study conducted by Bao et al., a pyrrolic nitrogen-doped carbon-based catalyst was synthesized by cultivating an NC layer on pre-formed silicon carbide particles, placing particular emphasis on identifying pyrrolic nitrogen as the active site [36]. Perez-Ramirez and colleagues synthesized nitrogen-doped carbon catalysts with varying electrical conductivities through the carbonization of aniline polymers [37]. They emphasized the role of a high pyrrolic nitrogen content in promoting reactant adsorption, while good conductivity additionally influences the surface diffusion of adsorbed species. These factors collectively contribute to the overall catalytic performance. In a separate study, Li and team prepared a CNH3 catalyst with a notable pyridinic nitrogen content through the thermolysis of ZIF-8 in an NH3 atmosphere [33]. Comparative analysis with the CN2 catalyst, characterized by a high pyrrolic nitrogen content, revealed that CNH3 exhibited superior catalytic performance, suggesting that the active site might be attributed to pyridinic nitrogen. Cao and colleagues employed walnut shell as a raw material to fabricate nitrogen-doped carbon catalysts with a high content of graphitic nitrogen through pyrolysis [38]. The catalyst's activity was attributed to the presence of graphitic nitrogen sites. In a separate study, Zhang and team induced the in-situ copolymerization of pyrrole and aniline, followed by thermal treatment to obtain a hollow structure-decorated carbon material derived from the copolymerization of polyaniline and pyrrole [39]. The material exhibited abundant pyridinic N + O − sites, which played a crucial role in activating HCl molecules and facilitating the reaction. However, it is worth noting that the current research on heteroatom-doped carbon often primarily focuses on analyzing potential active sites, potentially overlooking other properties of the material itself. In this investigation, we employed a soft template, namely, an ionic liquid, to dissolve naturally abundant casein, serving as a source of carbon and nitrogen, while MgCl2 functioned as a hard template to establish an expanded pore structure. Layered N-doped materials were synthesized at diverse carbonization temperatures, displaying exceptional catalytic performance in acetylene hydrochlorination reactions. Through a comprehensive analysis of the CN catalyst's performance and various parameters, we identified the essential properties that nitrogen-doped carbon catalysts should possess. Additionally, we utilized DFT theoretical calculations to scrutinize the active sites of the catalyst. The long-term experiments and regeneration studies on the catalyst demonstrate its tremendous industrial application prospects. The outcomes of this study provide insights into the design of non-metal-based acetylene hydrochlorination catalysts that align with industrial demands. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials The casein and hydrochloric acid (36–38 %) were purchased from Shanghai Titan. 1-Butyl-3-methylimidazole chloride (Bmim-Cl) was obtained from Shanghai chengjie. MgCl2 was purchased from Aladdin. Acetylene (C2H2, 98 %) and Hydrogen chloride (HCl, 99.999 %) was supplied by Hangzhou Minxing Chemical Technology Co., Ltd. All materials are without special treatment. 2.2 Catalyst preparation The CN materials derived from ionic liquids was prepared via a one-step method. First, weigh 20 g of ionic liquid and place it into a beaker, then heat it to 100 °C. Once the ionic liquid is completely melted, add 4 g of casein while maintaining the temperature at 100 °C and stirring at a speed of 300 r/min. After continuous stirring for 4 h, the casein is completely dissolved, and the mixture becomes a brownish sticky substance. Next, weigh 4 g of MgCl2 and add it to the mixture. Stir for 30 min, then pour the mixture into a quartz boat and subject it to pyrolysis in a tubular furnace. The gel-like mixture carbonizes into a black substance at high temperatures (600–900 °C). The resulting material is named CN-Mg-X, where CN-Mg-X represents a carbonization temperature of 600 °C. Subsequently, the obtained CN-Mg-X material is etched in a beaker containing 200 ml of hydrochloric acid (1 mol/ml) to remove Mg ions. After 12 h, clean several times the CN-X materials with deionized water and transfer it to an oven for drying. The resulting sample is named CN-X. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms of the investigated catalysts at 77 K were acquired using the Kubo X1000 gas adsorption instrument by BJ builder. Temperature-programmed analyses were conducted using the BJ PCA-1200 chemisorption analyzer, including C2H2 and HCl temperature-programmed desorption (TPD). In a typical experiment, approximately 100 mg of the sample was placed in a quartz reactor. Gaseous C2H2 or HCl gas (for TPD) was introduced into the quartz reactor at room temperature with a flow rate of 30 ml/min for 1 hour. Subsequently, helium (99.999 %, for TPD) was used to purge the samples and the pipeline for 1 hour. The reactor was then heated to 500 °C (for TPD) at a constant heating rate of 5 °C/min, while recording the C2H2 signal (TPD-MS) and HCl signal (TPD-TCD) data. Acetylene signals were detected using the Quantitative Gas Analysis Mass Spectrometer (QGA) from Hiden, UK. X-ray diffraction (XRD) spectra were recorded on a PANalytical-X'Pert PRO instrument. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was carried out using the ESCALAB 250 X-ray photoelectron spectrometer with Al Kα X-rays (1489.6 eV, 150 W, 50.0 eV pass energy). The morphology and structure of the catalyst were examined using a scanning electron microscope (SEM) manufactured by Hitachi. Defects in CN materials were analyzed using a confocal Raman microscopy system (HORIBA HR Evolution5). High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) was conducted using a Tecnai G2 F30 S-Twin microscope, operated at an acceleration potential of 300 kV (Uacc = 300 kV) with a cold-field emitter electron gun (∆E ≈ 0.35 eV). Samples were prepared by immersing a copper grid in an ethanol suspension of the solid and subsequently air-drying it. 2.4 Catalyst tests The performance testing of the prepared CN-Xs catalysts was conducted in a fixed-bed microreactor, as detailed in our previous work [26]. First, the required amount of catalyst (0.8 g) was loaded into the fixed-bed reactor (quartz tube). Prior to the reaction, the entire pipeline system was purged with nitrogen to eliminate the influence of water or other impurity gases on the reaction process Subsequently, the catalyst underwent treatment with HCl at 180 °C for 30 min. Following this, HCl (3 ml/min) and C2H2 (2.5 ml/min) were individually introduced into the reactor, the flow rates of each being meticulously regulated by separate mass flowmeters. Simultaneously, the temperature controller was employed to elevate the temperature of the catalyst bed to the desired set point (180 - 240 °C), maintaining a Gas Hourly Space Velocity (GHSV) of 90 h⁻¹ for C2H2. The gaseous effluent from the reactor system was subjected to treatment with a NaOH solution and subsequently analyzed using gas chromatography equipped with a Porapak N packed column (6 ft × 1/800 stainless steel). The peak areas were normalized for a thorough investigation of gas-phase products. The conversion was quantified by dividing the amount of reacted C2H2 by the total quantity of introduced C2H2. Selectivity to VCM was computed as the amount of VCM formed divided by the quantity of C2H2 reacted. Notably, the carbon balance, calculated based on these products, approached 100 % The conversion of acetylene and the productivity to VCM were calculated by Eqs. (1)-(2), as follows: (1) Acetylene conversion ( % ) = ( 1 − F A F A 0 ) * 100 % (2) Productivity = K g VCM K g cat . * h Where FA0, and FA represent the volume fraction of acetylene in the raw gas, and the volume fraction of remaining acetylene, respectively. 2.5 Computational details The mechanism governing acetylene hydrochlorination was elucidated through Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations employing the Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP). Electronic exchange-correlation calculations were conducted using the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) method with the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional. The interaction between the atomic nucleus and the valence electrons was modeled using the conjugated projection wave pseudopotential (PAW). A cutoff energy of 450 eV was applied for the plane wave basis set. Convergence was achieved utilizing the Gaussian smearing method with a bandwidth of 0.05 eV. The K-points mesh was optimized to 1 × 1 × 1 Γ-centered configuration. Convergence criteria for structure optimization and energy calculation were set at an energy convergence of 1.0 × 10–7 eV and an atomic force convergence of 0.05 eV/Å. The adsorption energies (Eads) of reactants or products on CN-Xs were calculated as part of the analysis. E ads = E sup + m o l e c u l e − E sup − E m o l e c u l e where Eads represents the adsorption energy; Esup+molecule represents the total energy of the adsorbed C2H2 or HCl with the model, Emolecule denotes the energy of the adsorbates in the ideal gas phase, and Esup indicates the energy of the N-containing model molecule. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization of the CN catalysts The porous CN materials employed in this study were prepared using a one-pot pyrolysis and etching process, as illustrated in Fig. 1 a. In this method, an ionic liquid was employed as a soft template to dissolve casein, thereby serving as a carbon and nitrogen source. Additionally, MgCl2 acted as a hard template, aiding in the creation of pores within the CN material. To analyze the morphology and structural features of the CN materials, scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) techniques were utilized. Figs. 1b and 1c depict the porous layered structure of the CN-800 material. Further TEM characterization results (Fig. 1d) reveal that the CN-800 material exhibits a web-like two-dimensional structure resembling fine gauze. In addition, EDS-mapping (Fig. 1e, Figure S1) was employed to analyze the elemental distribution on the surface of the CN-800 material. As shown in the figure, the spectroscopic results indicate that abundant C (yellow), N (green), and O (red) elements are uniformly distributed on the surface of the CN-800 material. Among them, carbon (C) has the highest content, followed by nitrogen (N), and oxygen (O) has the lowest content, consistent with the results of XPS spectra (Figure S2, Table S1). However, it is worth noting that MgCl2 was not detected in the EDS-mapping spectrum, likely due to its low Mg content on the CN-800 material's surface, rendering it undetectable. In the XPS spectrum (Figure S2, Table S1), only trace amounts of Mg elements were detected, indicating the effective removal of metallic Mg. This study underscores the substantial influence of pyrolysis temperature and etching processes on the physical properties and structure of the material. The results are detailed in Table 1 and Figure S3, which illustrate the physical properties of CN-X materials at varying pyrolysis temperatures. As depicted in Figure S3, all CN materials exhibit Type II nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms. Notably, at lower temperatures, CN-600 (202 m2 g‒1) exhibits a lower specific surface area. However, as the temperature surpasses 700 °C, both CN-700 (537 m2 g‒1) and CN-800 (535 m2 g‒1) materials demonstrate higher specific surface areas. Remarkably, at 900 °C, the CN-900 (485 m2 g‒1) material starts to experience a decrease in specific surface area, pore size, and pore volume, potentially attributed to pore collapse induced by excessively high temperatures. Additionally, elevated temperatures promote the formation of dense graphite-like carbon nitride structures, leading to a further reduction in the material's specific surface area. Following the surface morphology characterization of the material, we conducted comprehensive analyses focusing on the crystal phase, defects, and nitrogen-element doping structure utilizing spectroscopic techniques. Initially, X-ray diffraction (XRD) was employed to assess the material's crystal phase structure. As depicted in Fig. 2 a, all specimens exhibit two distinct peaks at 2θ = 24.5° and 2θ = 43.5°, corresponding to the (002) and (101) crystal planes of carbon materials, respectively. Notably, as the carbonization temperature increases, the (002) diffraction peak of CN materials shifts significantly to higher diffraction angles, indicating a reduction in the average interlayer spacing of the carbon material. This shift may be attributed to an augmented nitrogen doping content, leading to a decrease in the graphite phase of the material. Raman spectroscopy was applied to assess the level of graphitization and the extent of defects in CN catalysts prepared at various pyrolysis temperatures, with the aim of investigating the impact of temperature on the catalyst's structure and performance. Fig. 2b illustrates two distinct characteristic peaks appearing at wavenumbers approximately 1346 cm−1 and 1602 cm−1, corresponding to the D peak and G peak of carbon materials, respectively. The ID/IG ratio, commonly used to evaluate structural defects and graphitization degree, was employed. It is evident that as the pyrolysis temperature increases, the ID/IG ratio initially rises from 1.03 (CN-600) to 1.06 and then decreases to 0.97 (CN-900). This trend suggests that at higher temperatures, the generation of defect sites becomes more prevalent. Previous studies have indicated that material defects facilitate the exposure of active sites, ultimately influencing the catalytic performance. However, when the temperature rises to 900 °C, a significant graphitization phenomenon becomes evident in the carbon material, aligning consistently with the BET results. The types and contents of the elements in the CN materials were meticulously examined through X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) characterization. Data provided in Table S1 reveal that the predominant element in this catalyst is carbon (∼80 %). Due to the significant incorporation of N and O heteroatoms detected in the catalyst, the C 1 s XPS signal is resolved into six distinct species [44,45] (Figure S4 and Table S2). The CC sp2 peak (centered at 284.6 eV, content:∼62 %) is attributed to carbon atoms bonded exclusively to carbon neighbors, as found in graphite and amorphous carbon. The peak (content:∼17 %) at 285.5 eV is identified as C(Csp2-N), bonded with N through sp2 hybridization, as observed in pyridine and pyrrole, or as C existing in sp3 hybridized form. The third peak (content:∼10 %) at 286.1 eV can be attributed to CO (ether ground found in esters and lactone) or C N = O (nitrogen oxides). The fourth peak (content:∼3 %) is assigned to C = O (Pyridone) or NC = O (amide), located at 287.6 eV. Peaks at 288.1 eV and 289.1 eV are attributed to C = O (carbonyl, content:∼2 %) and OC = O (carboxyl, content:∼2 %), respectively. The last peak (content:∼2 %) at 291.1 eV corresponds to the π-π interaction of the carbon rings. Nitrogen doping acts as the primary active site for the catalyst. In the CN materials prepared in this study, a substantial nitrogen content is observed, particularly in CN-800, where the nitrogen content reaches 10.29 % (Table S1). Fig. 2c presents the XPS spectra of N 1 s along with the corresponding contents of various nitrogen species. The N 1 s spectrum displays four distinct peaks at 398.3, 400.3, 401.2, and 403.1 eV [44,46,47], corresponding to pyridinic nitrogen, pyrrolic nitrogen, graphitic nitrogen, and pyridinic N + O −. Data from Fig. 2d and Table S3 indicate that nitrogen primarily exists in the forms of pyridinic nitrogen and pyrrolic nitrogen. Notably, as the carbonization temperature increases, the content of pyridinic nitrogen and pyrrolic nitrogen in the catalyst gradually decreases. As indicated in Table S3, the content of pyridinic nitrogen decreases from 43.08 % (CN-600) to 33.64 % (CN-900), while the pyrrolic nitrogen content decreases from 45.65 % (CN-600) to 33 % (CN-900). Concurrently, there is an increase in graphitic nitrogen and pyridinic N + O −. Particularly at 900 °C, the transformation of nitrogen components toward graphitic nitrogen becomes more pronounced, escalating from 8.79 % (CN-600) to 25.23 % (CN-900). This shift is attributed to the high temperature favoring the transformation of CN materials into a denser structure, in accordance with the findings of Raman spectroscopy studies. The XPS spectra and corresponding fitting data for the elements O 1 s, Cl 2p, and Mg 1 s, which exhibit lower content in CN catalysts, are presented in Figure S5–7 and Table S4–6. Further detailed discussion is not provided in this section. 3.2 Catalytic performance In this study, following qualitative and quantitative analysis of the structural properties of CN catalysts and the content of various nitrogen-doped components, we proceeded to conduct performance tests for acetylene hydrochlorination utilizing the synthesized CN catalysts. Initially, tests were conducted on various CN-X catalysts under specific reaction conditions at 180 °C and a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 90 h −1. As depicted in Fig. 3 a, the acetylene conversion performance of the CN-600 catalyst is 43 %, and the catalyst's efficiency steadily improves with increasing temperature. Notably, the CN-800 catalyst exhibits the highest catalytic performance, achieving 81.6 %. This improvement can be attributed to the corresponding increase in the catalyst's specific surface area. However, at a carbonization temperature of 900 °C, the performance of the CN-900 catalyst experiences a significant decline, possibly due to the transformation of nitrogen species into non-active components, such as graphitic nitrogen. It is crucial to highlight that all catalysts demonstrate selectivity for vinyl chloride monomer (VCM) above 98 %, as depicted in Figure S8. Additionally, taking into account the potential influence of trace amounts of magnesium (Mg) detected by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), We tested the CN-Mg-X catalyst containing a significant amount of Mg components. Surprisingly, the performance of all catalysts was limited to approximately 10 % efficiency, as demonstrated in Figure S9. This observation suggests that Mg components does not have a significant catalytic effect on the acetylene hydrochlorination reaction. For the CN-800 catalyst, which demonstrated the most promising performance, further comprehensive performance tests were conducted. Illustrated in Fig. 3b and Figure S10b, the results showcase the performance of the CN-800 catalyst at an acetylene space velocity of 90 h −1 and varying reaction temperatures. The catalyst's efficiency increases proportionally with the elevation in reaction temperature. Upon reaching 220 °C, the CN-800 catalyst achieves its peak performance, recording an impressive 98.5 %. Further escalation of the temperature to 240 °C does not yield a significant enhancement in the catalyst's efficiency; instead, it marginally decreases to 96.5 %. This phenomenon could be attributed to excessively high temperatures limiting the contact adsorption process between the active sites of the catalyst and reactant molecules. Therefore, 220 °C appears to be the optimal reaction temperature for this catalyst. Furthermore, we assessed the performance of the CN-800 catalyst under varying acetylene space velocities. As depicted in Fig. 3c (Figure S10c), the catalyst exhibited catalytic efficiency exceeding 80 % at acetylene space velocities up to 180 h −1. However, a notable decline occurred when the velocity was increased to 1000 h −1, resulting in an acetylene conversion rate plummeting to 31.5 %. Fig. 3d and Table S7 present the VCM production data of various non-metallic catalysts reported in the literature. In comparison to these catalysts, the CN-800 catalyst developed in this study displayed exceptional performance at different space velocities. Specifically, under reaction conditions of 220 °C and an acetylene space velocity of 360 h −1, its VCM production reached a remarkable 1.38 KgVCM·h −1·Kgcat −1. 3.3 Catalytic descriptors evaluation In the preceding discussion, we briefly explored the impact of nitrogen-doped materials on catalyst performance. In this section, we have established a comprehensive correlation between various properties of CN materials and their catalytic performance, aiming to elucidate a more precise structure-performance relationship. This approach allows us to speculate further on the performance descriptors of nitrogen-doped carbon non-metallic catalysts in the acetylene hydrochlorination reaction. Illustrated in Fig. 4 a, the radar chart outlines the relationship between defects, physical properties, nitrogen (N), oxygen (O) doping content, and catalytic performance of different CN materials. From the Fig. 4a, it is evident that the NC-800 catalyst, displaying superior catalytic performance, possesses a higher specific surface area and more defects. This suggests that an elevated specific surface area and an increased presence of defects can enhance catalytic reactions. Notably, all CN materials, with the exception of CN-600, demonstrated negligible differences in specific surface area and defects. Consequently, there might be other crucial factors influencing the catalyst's catalytic performance. Upon examining the surface content of oxygen (O) and nitrogen (N) in various CN materials, it becomes evident that, in comparison to surface oxygen, nitrogen can more effectively enhance the catalyst's performance. The nitrogen content of the catalysts follows the sequence from high to low: CN-800 (10.29 %) > CN-700 (9.75 %) > CN-600 (8.35 %) > CN-900 (6.92 %). Notably, the catalytic efficiency of CN-600, despite having a higher nitrogen content, is lower than that of CN-900, which possesses a lower nitrogen content. This disparity could be attributed to the excessively low specific surface area and defects of the CN-600 catalyst, hindering timely contact between reactant molecules and the active nitrogen species (N). In summary, highly active non-metallic catalysts appear to necessitate a certain specific surface area and abundant nitrogen content. Furthermore, to establish a more detailed correlation between the various nitrogen-doped components and their respective catalytic performances, aimed at identifying the true active sites, we conducted an analysis. Contrary to our expectations, no significant correlation between the catalyst's activity and any single nitrogen component was observed, as depicted in Fig. 4b. Notably, the catalyst's efficiency exhibited a strong correlation with its pyridinic nitrogen and pyridinic N + O − components. This phenomenon suggests that pyridinic nitrogen and pyridinic N + O − may serve as potential active sites of the catalyst, facilitating the adsorption and activation of acetylene and hydrogen chloride reactants. In general, a catalyst's ability to adsorb and activate reactant molecules directly correlates with its catalytic performance. To explore potential active sites, we employed temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) techniques and Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations. Figs. 5 a and 5b respectively illustrate the hydrogen chloride (HCl) and acetylene (C2H2) TPD profiles of different CN-X catalysts. As depicted in Fig. 5a, the desorption temperatures of HCl follow this order: CN-800 (219 °C) > CN-700 (167 °C) > CN-900 (161 °C) > CN-600 (142 °C). Overall, as the carbonization temperature increases, the catalyst's adsorption strength for HCl gradually intensifies. The reduced HCl adsorption by the CN-900 catalyst can be attributed to the loss of nitrogen content. Fig. 5b reveals that all catalysts exhibit similar acetylene adsorption strengths, occurring at approximately 200 °C. However, CN-800 demonstrates a higher acetylene adsorption capacity compared to other catalysts. This phenomenon can be attributed to the abundance of π-functional groups (C = C/C = N, -COO) in this catalyst, enhancing its adsorption and activation capability for acetylene. These findings align consistently with the C 1 s XPS results (Figure S4). Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations were further employed to explore the adsorption capacities of different nitrogen (N) sites for C2H2 and HCl. As illustrated in Fig. 5c, the N sites of the catalyst exhibit stronger adsorption capabilities for hydrogen chloride compared to acetylene. Specifically, pyridinic nitrogen demonstrates a high adsorption energy of −1.14 eV for HCl, and it is noteworthy that the distance between H and Cl atoms in the HCl molecule increases from 1.27 Å to 1.937 Å (Fig. 5d). Additionally, pyridinic nitrogen with oxygen (pyridinic N + O −, −0.387 eV) also showcases robust adsorption capability for HCl, with the distance between H and Cl atoms elongated to 1.425 Å (Fig. 5g). This indicates that pyridinic N + O − possesses a strong adsorption activation capability for HCl and can serve as an active site for catalytic reactions. Meanwhile, pyrrolic nitrogen and graphitic nitrogen exhibit adsorption energies of −0.03 eV and 0.0014 eV for HCl, respectively, suggesting minimal interaction forces between them and HCl. It is noteworthy that when pyridinic nitrogen serves as the active site for HCl adsorption, a dissociation process occurs during the reaction. This results in the formation of a robust adsorption structure where the hydrogen (H) atom interacts with the pyridinic nitrogen site(N6H). We further demonstrate the presence of pyridine nitrogen protonation by differences in the electrochemical properties of the catalysts (Figure S12). The impact of protonated pyridinic nitrogen on the reaction was further examined, as depicted in Fig. 5c and 5h. The adsorption energy of the N6H site for HCl is −0.14 eV, and the distance between H and Cl atoms elongates to 1.318 Å (Fig. 5g). Considering the abundant presence of pyridinic nitrogen in the CN-800 catalyst, protonated pyridinic nitrogen (N6H) emerges as a potential active site for the catalytic reaction. In summary, doped pyridinic nitrogen with oxygen (NO), pyridinic nitrogen (N6), and protonated pyridinic nitrogen (N6H) in CN catalysts can serve as active species for the acetylene hydrochlorination reaction. This discovery aligns consistently with the results presented in Fig. 4b. 3.4 Long-term stability test and regeneration of the CN-800 catalyst Under accelerated deactivation conditions, a prolonged test was conducted on the CN-800 catalyst. As depicted in Fig. 6 a, the catalytic performance of the CN-800 catalyst gradually decreased from 74.5 % to 63.1 % in the initial 32 h, followed by an accelerated declining trend. After 50 h, the catalytic performance plummeted to 32 %. Subsequently, the catalyst underwent regeneration treatment after 50 h of reaction. Under a nitrogen atmosphere, the temperature controller was raised to 800 °C and held for 3 h of continuous high-temperature calcination. Later, the temperature was lowered to 220 °C, and the reaction gas was introduced for a second test. Building on the above study, we posit that highly active CN catalysts should possess a suitable specific surface area and higher doping of pyridinic N and pyridinic N + O −. Accordingly, BET and N 1 s XPS tests were conducted on CN-800–50 h and CN-800-Re catalysts. As shown in Fig. 6b, after 50 h of reaction, the catalyst's specific surface area decreased from 534 m2 g −1 to 43 m2 g −1. After high-temperature regeneration, the specific surface area of the catalyst recovered to 317 m2 g −1, and the performance of the CN-800-Re catalyst returned to 64.7 %. The data indicate that carbon deposition on the catalyst surface may be the main cause of catalyst deactivation as the reaction progresses. Figs. 6c, d, and Table S2 present N 1 s XPS data, showing a decrease in the content of pyridinic nitrogen and pyridinic N + O − after the reaction. After regeneration, the content of pyridinic nitrogen and pyridinic N + O − recovered to 37.51 % and 9.2 %, respectively. However, after high-temperature regeneration, the catalyst's graphitization significantly increased, and the nitrogen content doped in the catalyst decreased to 8.91 % (Table S1), which may be the reason for the incomplete recovery of the catalyst's initial activity. 4 Conclusions In summary, we synthesized a layered N-doped carbon catalyst using a dual-template method, demonstrating superior catalytic performance in acetylene hydrochlorination compared to non-metallic catalysts documented in the literature. By integrating experimental and characterization results, we observed a close relationship between the catalyst's performance and its surface area and nitrogen content. Further research suggests that protonated pyridinic nitrogen and pyridinic N + O − may serve as active sites for the catalyst, as they exhibit moderate adsorption strength of reactants. Long-term experiments and regeneration studies on the catalyst underscore its considerable prospects for industrial applications. The findings of this study provide inspiration for designing non-metal-based acetylene hydrochlorination catalysts that align with industrial demands. coredata.dc:description: Non-metallic catalysts present significant potential for environmentally friendly industrialization of acetylene hydrochlorination. However, the challenge of low activity in non-metallic catalysts hampers their practical application. In this study, we propose the use of a dual-template method to fabricate a layered N-doped carbon catalyst, subsequently applying it to acetylene hydrochlorination reactions. Experimental results indicate that the catalyst exhibits exceptional catalytic performance in acetylene hydrochlorination. Combined with characterization results, the catalyst's performance is positively correlated with its surface area and nitrogen content. Furthermore, DFT calculations suggest that protonated pyridinic nitrogen and pyridinic N + O − have moderate adsorption on HCl, potentially serving as active sites for the catalyst. This study analyzes the impact of various parameters of N-doped carbon catalysts on catalytic performance, providing direction for developing non-metallic catalysts suitable for industrial applications.
coredata.dc:title: Reaction-driven protonation of pyridine nitrogen as active sites for efficient acetylene hydrochlorination
